awd_titl_txt: GOALI/Collaborative Research: Optimal Inpatient Discharge Planning under Uncertainty
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this Grant Opportunity for Academic Liaison with Industry (GOALI) collaborative research award is to offer insights into improving patient flow through inpatient units and efficiently managing staff workload. This research will allow hospital managers to increase patient satisfaction and service throughput, policy makers to develop improved benchmarks for hospital workflows, and front-line providers to make intelligent data-driven decisions. Hospitals locally and nationally will be able to better align care processes, improve patient flow, all while lowering costs. Patients will have improved access to and quality of care. One of the concrete outputs of the project is a decision-support system that is expected to have have high potential for commercialization, and hence yield broad impact of the research, in the healthcare analytics market.

The research goals will be met via the development of a set of innovative models and solution approaches for analyzing and optimizing inpatient discharge decisions pertaining to patient flow alignment and care professional workload management. This work will help reduce inpatient discharge lateness and overnight stays, alleviate delays in transfers from upstream units, as well as balance discharge and non-discharge related workload for hospital staff. These improvements will be accomplished by optimally aligning bed-requests from upstream units with bed-releases from the inpatient unit. A novel decision-dependent stochastic combinatorial optimization framework will be developed that integrates inpatient discharge prioritization and workload scheduling decisions, which will be solved using an innovative scenario decomposition method. Rigorous theoretical derivation and comprehensive computational studies will be conducted for the proposed solution approach using real-data from our hospital partner.

por.por_cntn:
This is a collaborative research project with Dr. Nan Kong at Purdue University and Dr. Mark Lawley (now at Texas A&M University), and Dr. Nancy Pook (Kettering Medical Center). The research objective of this Grant Opportunity for Academic Liaison with Industry (GOALI) award was to offer insights into improving patient flow through inpatient units and efficiently managing staff workload. This work will help optimally aligning bed-requests from upstream units with bed-releases from the inpatient unit, and in turn reduce inpatient discharge lateness and overnight stays, alleviate delays in transfers from upstream units, as well as balance discharge and non-discharge related workload for hospital staff. The findings from this research will allow hospital managers to increase patient satisfaction and service throughput, policy makers to develop improved benchmarks for hospital workflows, and front-line providers to make intelligent data-driven decisions. Hospitals locally and nationally will be able to better align care processes, improve patient flow, all while lowering costs. Patients will have improved access to and quality of care.

From a scientific viewpoint, we several associated decision-making challenges. First, during the first two years, we worked closely with our GOALI partner (in Kettering Medical Center, Dayton OH) to understand their inpatient discharge planning process and the current difficulties with patient delays and waiting times for upstream patients. Given the practical need for an easy-to-understand and implementable strategy, we proposed an ‘n-by-T’ target discharge strategy for the unit staff, where ‘n’ is the number of all discharge-ready patients that should be discharged by the ‘T’th hour of that day. We evaluated this approach using actual data from the partnering hospital and evaluated its sensitivity on various inputs (e.g., number of discharge-ready patients, unit’s occupancy rate). We then presented this approach to the hospital’s leadership, upon which they piloted this in their Trauma Unit for 6 months. Retrospective evaluation of the pilot data revealed that our approach was able to reduce boarding times by nearly 15% and advanced the discharge completion times by nearly 2 hours. We then generalized this approach using data from a Neurology Unit at Maine Medical Center (Portland, Maine). The findings were very similar.

Second, during the last 3 years of this research, in close collaboration with our academic collaborators, we incorporated staff workload and schedules into our approach and developed two stochastic optimization approaches. In collaboration with Kong and Peck (Co-I), we developed a stochastic optimization model that focused on sequencing of all patients in the unit (i.e., newly-arriving, currently being treated, and discharge-ready) for an ancillary service provider (e.g., physical therapist, occupational therapist) accounting for the ASPs treatment times. We were able to show that easy-to-understand, implementable, strategies exist that are very close to the optimal solution. These strategies can be used by the ASP based on the inpatient unit’s size and number of patients to be discharged that day. In another collaboration with Kong and Lawley (Co-I), we developed a two-stage stochastic optimization model focusing on sequencing of patients for the RN. In this problem, we focused on maximizing a patient’s preference for a specific time of discharge during the day, while simultaneously minimizing delays in discharge-ready patients and upstream boarding.

From an impact standpoint, we were able to strengthen collaboration with hospital staff and develop awareness in their team on the use of data analytics and optimization approaches to develop understandable and implementable strategies, and also to benchmark existing approaches. Collaborations with several hospitals were developed, which included Kettering Medical Center (OH), Maine Medical Center (ME), and MD Anderson Center (TX). New collaborations have been established with international research to evaluate the generalizability of our findings in their country’s hospital systems.

Dissemination of these findings through both IE/OR and healthcare journals is likely to impact the way inpatient units are organized and planned when it comes to discharging patients. A web-based educational tool that can help both academic faculty and students, and hospital care providers, was hosted on our lab website. Several students (undergraduate and graduate) were partially funded on this project. The project helped enhance their written and oral communication skills, their professionalism through interactions with industry co-PIs, and their ability to handle complex problems and find elegant and relevant solutions. The PhD student who worked on this project is now working for a major healthcare system in Indianapolis, while another undergraduate student is now with a Children’s hospital. Specific aspects of this project have been integrated with my UG and Graduate courses, and shared during UG and Graduate student interactions as part of advising. We continue to disseminate our findings to healthcare providers who we continue to meet during interactions at local events and conferences.
